Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: The interaction of waves, tidal currents and river outflows and their effects on the delivery and resuspension of sediments in the near field
Award.AbstractNarration:
This study will focus on the mechanisms for sediment resuspension and removal in the near field of a river mouth plume characterized by a combination of strong freshwater discharge, significant vertical shear resulting from stratification, and strong surface wave conditions. It is hypothesized that the dispersal pathway of river-borne sediment is possibly more often governed by resuspension events in the region of sediment trapping, as opposed to only being an a priori property of the riverine discharge. Further, surface waves are hypothesized to be an important component of the overall physical mechanism of bottom stress and sediment resuspension in river mouths and coastal inlets, leading to greatly enhanced potential for sediment transport. In order to address these hypotheses, the researchers will further develop and utilize a nonhydrostatic model (NHWAVE) with capabilities to handle salinity stratification and suspended sediment in both wave-resolving and wave-averaged forms, using, in particular, results from ongoing NSF-funded work on river plume dynamics. The model will be validated against a high-resolution data set for instabilities in sheared buoyant plume flow in order to establish the accuracy of the formulation at high resolution, and against a larger scale transect of data from the Mouth of the Columbia River (MCR) to verify basic wave and circulation processes in the model. The model will be applied to the MCR in order to study the interplay of tidally pulsed river plume and waves and the resulting removal and resuspension of sediments in the vicinity of ebb-tidal plume liftoff, and will be further used in interpreting results from the ONR-sponsored RIVET-II experiment, conducted in June 2013.

Estuaries and river mouths provide the pathway for riverine supply of sediments to the coast and the distribution of sediments to the shelf and deep ocean. This project will study the influence and coupling of tidal currents, river discharges and surface waves in determining the sediment transport regime in coastal inlets. The first task will be to develop and test both wave-resolving and wave averaged versions of a flexible, parallelized nonhydrostatic model NHWAVE, which has recently been extended to incorporate density stratification and the presence of a suspended sediment load, thus providing the basic tools needed for high resolution process studies. The further development of the model is important for several reasons. First, the strong vertical components of motion associated with the tidal genesis of fronts in surface advected plumes, and the occurrence of strong resuspension events near regions of plume liftoff, require the application of fully nonhydrostatic models. In addition, wave processes in strongly sheared flows associated with surface-advected plumes are not adequately described by either existing wave resolving models or by theory for wave-averaged flows in weakly sheared environments as presently used in standard coastal ocean models, thus requiring improved model formulations.

This research will advance the understanding of sedimentation processes at the intersection of river and coastal environments. The model development effort will further the recent trend towards use of nonhydrostatic formulations in coastal ocean models by incorporating wave-resolving capabilities, leading to the ability to represent a full range of wave, current, stratification, turbulence and sediment processes in a common computational framework utilized at realistic scales. The resulting model will greatly enhance the community's ability to assess the effect of complex, irregular wave processes on bottom stress and sediment resuspension, leading to a better understanding of the pathways for sediment motion from river to shelf. The resources from the grant will partially support three doctoral graduate researchers, and undergraduate summer fellows through an existing REU program. The PIs will continue their efforts to promote science and research to a K-12 population through continued and expanded participation in University of Delaware programs such as Coast Day, Engineering Cool Stuff Camp and Young Engineers Camp.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Testing of Sediment Module in NHWAVE

The ODU team has developed a sediment module in the non-hydrostatic model  NHWAVE, which includes both the cohesive and non-cohesive sediment transports. In this module, the flow and suspended sediment are simulated in a coupled manner. The suspended sediment may affect the flow field in three aspects: (1) The presence of suspended sediment increases mixture density, introducing horizontal density variations and baroclinic pressure gradient forcing (baroclinic forcing effect); (2) The vertical distribution of suspended sediment concentration creates a stably stratified water column, damping the flow turbulence (turbulence damping effect); (3) The suspended sediment also produces a stably stratified bottom boundary layer, altering the logarithmic velocity profile near the bottom and reducing drag coefficient (bottom boundary layer effect). The alteration of flow field by sediment will subsequently affect its suspension. 

The NHWAVE has also been improved and enhanced in terms of accuracy and efficiency by using Pressure Decimation and Interpolation (PDI) method as well as elimination of unneeded approximations in representations of boundary conditions for stresses and fluxes. The new code has been integrated into an open source coastal modeling system, which is available from GitHub.

Frontal features of the Columbia River plume unveiled by the high-resolution non-hydrostatic model NHWAVE

The high-resolution, non-hydrostatic coastal model, NHWAVE, is used to simulate ebb processes at MCR with an aim to resolve the frontal structures and coherent structures as the ebb flow approaches the north jetty and gets diverted. The NHWAVE domain covers the mouth region, and high spatial resolution of ~15m mesh size and 40 vertical layers are used. The model is able to predict the salinity anomaly on the water surface, which is believed to be associated with observed thermal fingers. The current field in the interrupted region is modulated by the frontal structures, indicated by the vorticity field calculated from both the numerical model and data measured by an interferometric synthetic aperture radar.

The model results indicated that large amplitude shear instabilities are generated due to internal hydraulic jumps as the plume moves over bathymetric sills and a lateral boundary inclined to the plume front. In this case, simulation results indicate that the Kelvin-Helmholtz billows have sufficiently large amplitudes to interrupt the water surface, causing the prominent features of stripes on the surface.

In summary, the model results revealed that an internal hydraulic jump occurs after the plume reaches North Jetty during the maximum ebb tide. Large amplitude shear instabilities are generated downstream from the hydraulic jump front, which leads to the entrainment of pockets of saltier water approaching the surface. The surface expression of these instabilities and the entrained pockets of saltier water may be responsible for the O(100 m)-scale finger pattern observed between the front and the jetty by the airborne radar. The modeled vorticity field shows the finger pattern consistent with the vorticity field derived from the ATI-SAR data. Vertical profiles from the model revealed strong vertical motions, suggesting significant non-hydrostatic effects. The vertical advection not only causes thermal/salinity divergence but also local convergence/divergence of flow velocity and hence can be detected by IR and Radar imagery.

Flood conditions in the Mouth of Columbia River

To better understand the flow structure during flood condition at the mouth of Columbia River (MCR), 3D non-hydrostatic simulation of the flood tide was carried out using NHWAVE. In particular, we like to understand the surface signatures associated with the landward migration of a bottom saline current in MCR so that we can provide more insights to interpret remote sensing imagery. Simulation results also exhibit strong surface velocity divergence associated with the front of the bottom saline current at different instants during flood. A closer examination of the velocity divergence at the surface and salinity distribution near the bottom during the flood tide reveals that the patterns of the former matches very well with the latter, and vertical distribution of the velocity vector shows that the propagation of the front can generate velocity field in the water column that is sufficiently intense to leave surface signatures. However, limited by the resolution, more detailed flow structures, such as shear instabilities associated with the sharp density interface, cannot be captured (to resolve shear instabilities, a spatial resolution of sub-meter is needed). In summary, non-hydrostatic numerical results confirm that this strong velocity divergence is indeed due to a bottom-hopping salt front migrating landward during flood. It is worth mentioning that when we re-run the case without solving the dynamic pressure (i.e., hydrostatic simulation), we can still observe similar surface signature. Careful examination suggests that during the passage of the front, it mainly induced large horizontal velocity gradient, which can still be captured by the hydrostatic model.
